head.title: Let's Keep the Lights On: Some Expert Advice for Con Ed; Can We Blame The Weather?

hedline.hl1: Let's Keep the Lights On: Some Expert Advice for Con Ed; Can We Blame The Weather?

abstract.p: Op-Ed article by Brattle Group chairman Peter Fox-Penner, in light of recent blackouts in Queens, holds US power grid must be redesigned to deal with extreme weather (S)

block.p: AN aging distribution system may be implicated in New York's recent blackouts, but there are longer-term forces at work here.

On the positive side, new technologies are available that monitor the distribution system and automatically report overloads and blackouts. In New York, where reliable power is vital, the distribution system should be state-of-the-art.
AN aging distribution system may be implicated in New York's recent blackouts, but there are longer-term forces at work here.

On the positive side, new technologies are available that monitor the distribution system and automatically report overloads and blackouts. In New York, where reliable power is vital, the distribution system should be state-of-the-art.

But the power failure in Queens was the combined effect of a prolonged heat wave, intense rains and a tornado. Severe weather like this -- perhaps the early effects of global climate change -- are increasing in frequency and intensity.

The United States power grid must be redesigned to deal with this extreme weather. Although it is easy to blame utilities when blackouts occur, state and federal leadership and a willingness to pay for grid upgrades have been lacking. A smarter, stronger grid is a national priority, not just New York's problem.
Peter Fox-Penner is the chairman of the Brattle Group, a consulting firm that advises utilities and energy companies. A principal of the firm has a proposal pending with Con Edison.
